div.head: THE ALLIANCE.
div.p: Our telegrams announce that the "Daily Telegraph" is advocating the$ strengthening of the Anglo-Japanese alliance, and wo are told that this policy of our London contemporary is receiving general approbation in the City. Our present treaty with Japan may be taken to express the accepted policy as far as concerns the matters with which it deals, by Great Britain recognizes Japan's. Chinas her special interests in Mauchuna, aid her right to take steps to protect them it stipulates that if in the protector oi time interests Japan should at war with a third Power Great Britain will be, and that if during sued war any other should join against Japan Great will than take part in the war as me ally in Japan The war now going on is covered by the treaty. Great Britain is neutral, but it any Power should come Russia's assistance Great Britain must assist Japan. Thu treaty, as has just been said, represents the accepted policy. But it doss not constitute a policy, fur it is merely a fragment, dealing with special interests and specific eventuates. It provides certain means for facilitating the default Oi Japanese and of British interests in the Ear > East The eventualities which it contemplates, I however, are only a part oi those which may l happen j perhaps not the most immediately j probable part

In view of the recent victory of Japan, it might not be improbable that the Russia autocracy, id order to save itself Iron revolu­tion at home, would user atoll to tha utmost to obtain help from another Power. This contingency, not highly pro liable, is quite within the of pos­sibility, and for that event the Brit: h nation ought to be prepared, and the Government in particular ought to be every respect ready. Readiness means having decided beforehand on the necessary plans of campaign, including all arrangements and the faros to be used, and not having when the time cines to sit dews and deliberate if anything is to be done, and if | so what it is to be. It would be natural: - sup-1 pose that after the flourishes of the Uabiuei on H the subject of its how disposition of our naval i squadron, Committee ot Deleuce, its War itself, and all its other military "reforms''! the anything,
and that if at any moment any Powers-should show signs of lifting a huger against Japan the order would be given and the British Fleets, be next day of the wa
y to their posts. But experience shows that which have
been unready once ate quite capable of being unready again.

div.head:
THE WAR
ANOTHER JAPANESE ADVANCE
LINDEVITCH TO PURSUE FABIAN TACTICS

div.p: General Lindevitch is taking measures to cope with the Japanese turning movement.(Havas)
The Japanese are again advancing. They caused the Russian reargaurd to retreat 13 miles to xxx, which is 40 miles to the south of Gutzuling.(Reuter)

It is uderstood that the intention to mobilize on a large scale has been abndoned for the present. Only drafts of sufficient strength to stiffen Linievitch's army will be sent. Te General will pursue Fabian tactics. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE JAPANESE LOAN
SCENES IN LONDON

div.p: The bankers state they are receiving many French subscriptions for the American version of the Japanese loan.(Reuter)

The exterior of the bamks which are issuing the Japanese loan resembles Boxing Day at the theatres. Special police are preserving order. There are long queues of persons outside the banks, the largest being around the Hong Kong and Shanghai office. It is certain that the loan will be heavily oversubscribed.(R)

The "Daily Telegraph", in taking up the idea of strengthening the alliance between Britain and Japan, says that the suggetion is receiving general approbation in the City. This will especially be the case if the idea enjoys the moral support of America.(Reuter)

A systematic constitutional agitation has begun in Finland and is spreading considerably. A demonstration at Abo was attended by 20,000 persons. Crowds are parading the streets waving revolutionary flags; bands are playing national airs.(Reuter)
H.M. cruiser "Lancaster" has arrived here.(Reuter)
Five Cardinals have sent M.Loubet a protest in favor of the Concordat.(Havas)
The Cabinet has been formed with Signor xxxx as President and Signor Tittoni as minister for Foreign Affairs.(Havas)

1.Sansovino; 2.Catty Crag; 3.Ranger II. 18 ran. Won by a head,neck dividing second and third. Starting Price Betting: 100 to 9 against Sansovino, 11 to 2 against Catty Cray, and 25 to 2 against Ranger II. (R)

div.head:
THE TROUBLES OF RUSSIA
THE CRIMEAN DISTURBANCES
VIOLEN OUTBREAKS IN CAUCASUS

div.p: The disturbances begn here on Sunday evening when the town was ignited in five places. The crowd obstructed the work of extinguishing the themes. All the police stations were wrecked and the prisoners liberated the attempt to sack the municipal treasury wa frustrated. (Reuter)

Violent outbreaks are occuring in many parts of the Caucasus both in the town and country. The peasants declare that they can only obtain concessions by force, and they are, therefore, attacking the municipal buildings and the country seats of the nobles. The Government is sending troops into the district. There is a marked recrudescence of unrest throughout Russia, apparently in pursuance of a "mot d'ordre." (Reuter)
Warships and military reinforcements have arrived here. Order has been restored(R)

On the 25th and 26th inst. 34 vessels passed through the Canal, the receipts for the two days being frs. 815,022,84. 15 of the ships were British, 2 Italian, 9 Russian, 3 Greek, 5 German. The total receipts from the 1st inst. amounted to frs. 9,087,41299.
A.L.M. & D.S.-

At the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute last night, a lecture was given under the auspices of the above society b the Rev. Reginald Rynd, BA, on the "The Natural Use of the Voice". A ggrsat deal of valuable information was conveyed by the lecturer as to the proper mode of developing the vocal organs, and his description of the various reasonant organs of the human frame- in themselves very lucidly described-was rendered still more plain by a large diagram of the head and throat, The importance of the proper management of the resonant organs, nd the way in whic to best avoid the hindrances to good singing, presented by the tongue, throatiness, etc., were fully set forth, and at the close of the lecture the appreciation of the audiece as plainly expressed. A vote of thanks to the reverend lectuer was proposed by Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, KCMG, who presided, and was heartily accorded. We hope that Mr.Rynd wll favor he society with many more of these interesting contributons to the proper understanding of music, nothwithstanding the discouragingly small number of members who turned up last night.

div.head: TERRIBLE ACCIDENT
div.p: THREE MEN BURIED ALIVE

A terrible accident occurred at Alexandria yesterday afternoon about 5 o'clock, by which three men lost their lives. In Stamboul street, just behind Groppi's establishment, building operations are proceeding, and at the time mentioned the foundations of the house being built gave way, burying three native masons in the debris. Towards evening, the dead bodies of two of the men were recovered, while the other remained buried under a mass of earth and stone. From investigations which we have made, it appears that at a depth of four metres these men were engaged in building up the earth i nthe form of an arch. Th carelessness of native workmen is notorious. It seems that in forming the arch they had taken away some earth on the side of the escarpment. This weakened the layer of earth on top and caused the landslip. Under the circumstances the blame for the unfortunate accident must fall on the victims themselves, as no one but they can tell the stability of their position. Had they been simple workmen, the responsibility would lie with the employers, who should have capable overseers.

div.head: AL AZHAR UNIVERSITY
div.p: The third uhma of the Al Ahzar University, Sheikh Ahmed el Hanbali, has resigned his seat in the council of directors of the University. Two sheikhs only remain, Sheikh Hassanein El Boulaki and Sheikh Hassanein El Edoui. We hear on good authority that candidates for cadi hip will near future, after passing an examination at Al Azhar at an early period of their studies there, go through a special course of training which will be entirely independent of the ancient university

div.head: UPPER EGYPT HOTELS COMPANY
div.p: Referring to the announcement which appeared in our columns yesterday, we are informed that the Savoy Hotel, Assouan, will not now be included in the above company, as stated, owing to the fact that the necessary arrangements have not been concluded with the Anglo-American Company. The capital of the new company is 220,000, in shares of 4 each, snd 100,000 in 5% first mortgage debentures. The directors will be Mr. AE Harrison, general manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son, (Egypt), Ltd, George Nungovich Bey, Mr. Charles Baehler, and Mr. Pagnon.

div.head: STATE OPERA
div.p: We hear that a petition is circulating among the abonnes of the Khedival Opera House (and obtaining numerous signatures), copies of which will be addressed to the Minister of Public Works and to Lord Cromer, Mr Vincent Corbett and Sir William Gastin. The petitiondeals with the decision of the Socitete Artistique to bring an Italian company over in the season 1905-1906, in spite of the decision taken some time ago, and aproved by the Government, to bring French companies over in alternate years. The signatories of the petition complain of this breach of the regulations pointing out that the arrangement previously made enabled good new operas (which by the concession must be produced to the number of four a year) to be brought before the Cairo public. They disclaim all nationalist bias and assert that the plea of the societe Artistique, viz, that a good French company cannot be procured, is utterly untenable. They therefore beg the Minister of Public Works to intervene on behalf of the Government and the public. In our opinion the best way out of the difficulty would be to revoke the concession as soon as possible, and hand over the entire business to a good impressario.. The proverb "Too many cooks" is alarmingly true in Egypt.

div.head: CAIRO ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS
div.p: Many additions have been made to the menagerie in these gsrdens during the last two months, and one of the prettiest sights now to be seen near Cairo is that of the young gazelles and ibex, of which more than a dozen have recently been born at Ghizeh, playing and frisking about with their mothers in the large paddock which occupies the site of the ruins of the old palace. The births thi spring also include an Arui wild sheep and two Hedjaz sheep, and among the birds, besides numerosu doves of various kinds, two buff-backed egrets have been hatched and reared. Seventeen animals have been presented: an Egyptian weasel by Mrs. Colville, a hawk-eagle by Mr. H. Raczinski of Alexandria, a Nilotic waran-lizard from Luxor by Prof. Dr. G. Schweinfurth, a ring-necked parakeet by Mrs.Bazil, three slender lorises by Mr. J.A. Tarrell, a jungle cat by Mr.AE Branch, seven trumpeter bullfinches and a spotted cuckoo by Mr. GH Malcolm, an a greyheaded love-bird by Mr. S. Hanauer. The purchases during the same period include a yellow baboon, avery larg bonnet-monkey, a white nosed red monkey, some lemurs, two species of wild cat, a Loder's gazelle from the Fayoum, a mouse deer from India, several pretty species of birds not previously represented in the collection, as the lavender finch of Tropical Africa and the Pein nightingale, also two Mina birds, and finally an Algerian tortoise.
By the kind permission of the Inspector General of Prisons, the band of the Ghieh Boys' School will play on Friday afternoons in the gardens throughout this year.

div.head: THE SIRDAR AT SUAKIN
RECEPTOON BY INHABITANTS
div.p: During his recent visit to Suakin, the Sirdar distributed several robes and other valuable gifts, such as medal dresses, watches, revolvers, knives, and shaving articles, to a large number of sheikhs of tribes, clergy, and faithful guides and attenants for their loyal services these few years to the Government. After this ceremony was over he delivered an eloquent address in English which lasted 45 minutes, and which was then interpreted into Arabic by his Arabic secretar, Shaheen Bey, and afterwards again interpreted into Hadendow by the Commandant of Police, Mohamed Bey Ahmed.

In the evening his Excellency was entertained at dinner at the Moudirieh. Afterwards a reception was held, when Saghcolaghassi Aly Effendy Ahmed,Deputy-Inspector of Suakin Moudirieh, addressed his excellency the Sirdar in English as follows: "Your Excellency,-I have been chosen by the Egyptian officers, officials and employes of the Government of Suakin to stand respectfully before your Excellency and to express their happiness on your visit to this province and town. All the people of whatever station, the richest and the poorest, the highest and the lowest, have taken this oppurtunity to welcome you by their shouts and respond to the consideration and goodwill you have ever shown to all. All whom you find around you are anxious to assure you of their warm feelings and pleasure. The whole Sudan recognises and is grateful for the wise and good administration of the coutnry. The whole Sudan recognises and is ggrateful for the manner in which the happiness and well-being of all classes are considered. Not only the whole Sudan, but the whole world recognises the spledid way in which the country has thriven during the years which you have been Sirdar and Governor General of the Sudan, and wonders at the magnificent manner in which the resources of the coutnry are being developed. It is true that during this period all departments of the GOvernment have accomplished much, but in this province we watch perhaps more keenly than others, the miles of railway which are joining the Nile and Red Sea, and the plans for the development of the ports of the Sudan. We know that all that has been the result of your master spirit and encouragement. I am not able to express all that is on my mind, but specially we would thank your Excellency for the honor of your visit to us this evening, and in this way showing that you have a warm heart and kind feelings for all those serving the Government of this country. I ask all who are present to drink the health of his Excellency the Sirdar of the Egyptian Army and the Governor-General of the Sudan, El Ferik Sir Francis Reginald Wingate Pasha." The following congratulatory order was published after the Sirdar's departure:-El Miralai Howard Bey, Mr. Kerr, and the military officers and officials of the Egyptian Army and Sudan Government for their admirable arrangements for his recetion, and for their good and hard work to which the very marked improvement in the condition and progress of the town and province since his last inspection in 1901 is due. "He was much struck with the smartness and turn out of the guard of honor furnished by the 3rd Battalion, and the excelence of the organisation and the careful arrangements made for the treatment of the sick in the military and civil hospitals. The interest taken in education as evinced by the satisfactory state of the school and scholars, was most marked. He also wishes you to convey to El Miralai Macauley Bey his great appreciation of the hard and valuable work done by him and his staff on the new Railway, of which the substantial progress already made is the best testimony. In conclusion he would like to express to you, your officers and officials, and to all classes of people of Suakin, his cordial thanks for the loyal and hearty reception on his arrival and hospitatlity extended to him during his stay." (Signed): LO Stack, Kaimakam, Mil. and Private Secretary.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner "Tabor" arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning. The SS "Grecian Prince", from Manchester, left Malta on Monday and is due here on Friday next, with passengers and general cargo. The SS Crypian Prince, from Antwerp, left London on Monday last, with passengers and general cargo for Malta and Alexandria.

div.head: CANON DAVIS MEMORIAL
DEDICATION SERVICE
div.p: The short service held by the Bishop in Jerusalem and the East at 4:45pm on Monday in St. Mark's Church was quite private. It had not been possible to fix the exact hour until the day before, too late t announce it in the "Gazette". The Bishop, who was attended by his acting chaplain, the Rev. Canon Ward, inserted the following special prayers in a shortened form of evening service. "In the faith of Jesus Christ we dedicate this memorial stone, now handed over to the charge of the chaplain and the trustees of St. Marks Church, to the peretual memory of the Csnon Edwin John Davis, MA i nthe church in which he s long ministered. May those who worship here, and face his effigy as they go out from this House of God into the world, hear in memory the example of one of whose loving and charitable labours for the good of Christ's poor, should stimulate the spirit of charity in others; and whose watchful care of the interests of this foundation of St. Mark's has left to his successors great possibilities for happy influence in the chaplaincy which he served for so long a time. "Assist us mercifully, O Lord, in these our supplications and prayers, and in this our act of thy servants towards the attainment of everlasting salvation, that among all the changes and chances of this mortal life we may ever be defended by Thy most gracious and ready help; through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen"

div.head: LA DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Delegation Municipale s'est reunie le 28 mars 1905 a 4h. pm sous la presidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli. La Delegation arrete parmi le programme des routes a faire cette annee. Les devis at cahier des charges devront etre presentes au fur et a mesure au College pour la mise en adjucation. Elle adjuge a M. Degiarde la furniture de 60 bancs et 40 chaises pour le jardin Nousha; la route de Ramleh, a M Erriques; enfin la fourniture de balais et couffins, a MM Abdel Rahim Hekel et a M Stamatepoulo. Les offres presentes pour la demolition d'une maison, rue Sinadino, n'ayant pas para satisfaisantes, la Delegation decide de refaire une nouvelle adjucation pour ce travail. La Delegation renvoie au sujet de la construction de la conduite de raccordement pour le deversement des eaux de lavage des nouveaux filtres. Elle proposera a la Commission l'overture d'un credit supplementaire de LE 600 pour le jardin Nouzhe. La seance est le ee a 8h. pm.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: THEATRE ZIZINIA
NOTRE JEUNESSE

Avec la representation de Notre Jeunesse, la compagnie Coquelin Cadet a pu enregistrar une de see crations, et M. Jean Coquelin s'y est autant distingue dans le role de Lucien Briant qu'avanthier dans celui du marquis de La Seigliere Quant a Mme Moreno, elle a su rendre a la perfection deux ou trois soenes pathetiques qui lui ont valune ovation. Nous devons encore une mention particuliere a Mme Bouchetal et a l'heureuse interprete du role de Luoienne Briant qui ont ete toutes deux justement remarquees. M. Coquelin Cadet a termine la representation par trois monologues qu'il a debite d'uue facon exquise. Ce soir Lee Romanesques, comedie en trois actes de M. Edmond Rostand, et L'Ete de la Sanit Martin, comedie en un acte de MM. Meilhac et Halevy.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Major General Sir Ronald Lane and Lieutenant General Sir Thomas Kelly Kenny, who have respectively held the positions of Military Secretary and Adjucant General to the British Army, are leaving Egypt on Monday next by the Bibby SS Staffordshire from Port Said Sir Ronald Line is staying with Mr. Gould until tomorrow when he returns for a few days to Cairo.
Yesterday Sir Ronald paid a visit to Victoria College in company with Mr. Gould and was very much pleased with this institution.

The "Journal du Cairo" remarks:- On donne comme probable la nomination de M. Sheldon Amos, juge au Tribunal indigene de re instance du Caire, comme conseiller a la Cour d'appel indigene en remplacement de M. Coghlan.
The Italian man of war "Liguria" is expected to arrive at Alexandria shortly with the Duke of the Abruzzi, who is on his way home after a voyage round the world.

It is not generally known that the credit for the suggestion of England's purchase of the "St. James Gazette", whose 75th birthday is to be celebrated by a banquet in London. When an oppurtunity offered of buying the Suez Canal shares which now form so important a national asset, it was Mr. Greenwood who suggested the purchase to Disareli. Disareli jumped at it, and the thing was done. The statesman got the kudos, but to the journalist belongs the credit.

Egypt has been from the beginning the background for a career of much distinction in the case of Captain Colin Keppel, who has been recently appointed to succeed Sir A Milne in command of His Majesty's yachts. During the attempt to relieve General Gordon, in the subsequent rescue of Sir C. Wilson under Lord Charles Beresford, on the Nile in 1898, when he commanded the flotilla, and at the CB, Captain Keppel won unqualified praise for his ability and courage. As a midshipman be participated in the bombbardment of Alexandria.
Mr JIR Dempster, whose sudden death we annonced yesterday, was chief engineer of the New Egyptian Compsnys Nile reclamation works.
Mr.ALP Weigall has been appointed inspector to the Antiques Service at an annual salary of LE 400.
The Rev. Alf. A. Cooper, MA, of the British and Foreign Bible Society, is expected back in Alexandria on the 1st prox. Mr. Cooper travels by way of Berlin, Vienna, and Constantinople.

The following officers have been granted leave of absence on private affairs:- Capt. S.J.Somerville and 2nd Lieut.CEG Varnon, 2nd Royal Inniskiling Fusiliers; Liet Col. Berks. Regt., Capt.GB Byrne and 2nd Lieut RSW Walpole, 2nd Rifle Brigade; Liet. TC Cunningham, AOD. Major EJ Lawson, AVD.

Mais tandis qne les diverse» nations euro­péen ne», ponr favoriser Leur exportation, riva­lisaient dans l'attribution de primes de pins en plu forte*, les Etats-Unis imposaient le* sucre» importés dan» k proportion oh ils avaient été favorisée ; ce qui amena k convocation d'an Congrès à Bruxelles où le principe des primes fut aboli.'Seule k Russie a refuré d'adhérer aux alarmes de cette fameuse convention desti­née 4 marquer us data mémorable dans 1m annales de l'industrie sucrière.
Le stwre de betterave, qui était tombée arti- $oi«il«Mat 4 de très bu pii* ne pourra pree-
que pins être exporté 4 causa de le concumna du sucre de oann* qui reprendra sa place pré pondérante dan» le marché mondial

Une surproduction cependant n'oit pas i craindre l'parue que la production H trouvera nécessairement limitée par la manqua d'ex per ration, par la suppression due primo» do labri- cation et par la réduction de la culture do lu otittorave, 2* parce qu'il y a tandem» dam certain» paya peur venir en aide 4 l'agriculture et à Tiadootne, d'augmenter la waauinmaUon A l'intérieur par la rédaction de» droit*. CW ainsi qu'en franco M. Bouvier, prévoyant le a la f'rauce qui exportait jusque-là 670 mille tonnes de sucre par an, réduisit en septembre
l'impôt sur la fabrication du ancre de Ir. 64 à fc. 25 par quintaL
Ce dégrèvement a eu pour résultat de faire passer la oousununatiou pendant 1 exercice 1993-

de 455.762 tonnes à 613.944 tonnas. La diminution de 37 œntunes par Kg, dans l'impôi a donc produit uae augmentation dans la con­sommation locale de 158.182 tonnes en une seule année, soit 33, ? %. fendant oes huit dernières années la consommation a anoore augmenté de 34 % sur la période correspon­dante de L'année dernière, il. Bouvier pont à juste titre être fier de cette mesure,qui pouvait paraître téméraire au début, mais qui est aujourd'hui couronné du plus brillant suocès. Maintenant que l'expérience est faite, il est à souhaiter que les autres pays suivent l'exemple de La Ÿrance.

Le relèvement doa prix du sucre permettra en outre da remettre en état les a ombreuses ueines des Antilles qui étaient tombées en ruine oes dernières années ; elles ne pourront peut-être plus compter sur le marché européen, yùle sacre de betterave sera consommé sur place, mais elles 'suffiront à peine à pourvoir à la consommation américaine qui est, comme on le sait, formidable.

L'Angleterre et l'Orient resteront des mar­primes L'Egypte aura gagné non seulement des débouchés extérieure nouveaux mais encore reconqnis son propre marché, qui ne consom­mait- plus que les sucres dite de Trieste.

L'industrie du pays restera donc maltresse 'du marebé malgré la hausse des prix qui sers eu temps normal de '10 ir. par 10U Kg. sur les marchés antérieure. La Société doa Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte qui a pu traverser le» crises terribles où tant d'autres entreprises similaires ont sombré,et qui depuis l'achat dus sucreries de la Daïra tiauieb, représente 4 elle proctiré k Uonvenûun do Bruxelles 4 l'indus- triu auarière.

U est partant difficilede s'expliquer comment alors que le sucre hausse do prix (50,60 %) et que le» affaires augmentent, lés actions de k société de* sucrera.-» sent en baisse. Nous sa­vons qu'en Europe l'industrie sucrière tra-

w une crise aiguë dans la période actuelle transition et après une recolle exception- bellement mauvaise, Mais eu Egypte où k Convention a assuré an brillant avenir anx sacres et où Je mouqae de plaie et les variations atmosphériques né sont pas 4 crain­dre ponr les récolte», grâce 4 l'eau du Nil, non» ne Comprenons paa on vérité pourquoi le» valeurs sucrières locales doivent suivra dans leu» fluctuations les valeurs sucrières étran­gères qui sont en général très dépréciées sur tous les Tnirchés européen* depuis le nouvel eut de choses.

il y a bien un rapport entra les deux, Ainsi de valeur, mais il ait d'un effet opposégenres l'industrie égyptienne bénéficiera de tous les désavantages que la nouvelle convention a créé* pour l'industrie européenne. la ruine et le» perte» de celle-ci se traduiront ponr celle-là en.bénéfice ut en prospérité.

L'examen même artificiel da k question des sueras aurait suffit pour édifier la premier venu. Mais eu Bourse on ne raisonne guère on vous répondra que Le» Calculateurs avec leurs études et leu» paperasse» y perdent perdent générale- meut leur fortune. Voilà pourquoi daus la Bourse d'Alexandrie comme dans celle da Paris les cours montent et descendent en dépit du bon sens. Les préjugé», tihumenr et l'état d'esprit de quelques-uns sufEàeut pour donner souvent le ton au marché. Un n'est jamais plus moutonnier qu'en Bourse.

Ajoutons 4 propos de cotte Société que le» importation» de sucre brut; effectué» pour wn compta sent exfionérés actuellement de tou* l'enouuragornent de k culture de 1a caune à suera, le (iouversement a déd ié de réduire dons de fortes proportions les droits de fabri­cation payés jusqu'ici. Les énormes quan­tités de sucre importés par la Société por­tés sur Je» statistiques douanières de l'année dernière doivent lui avoir procuré aux prix actuel* un béuéfico net de £ 400.009 sur les prix d'achat, du plus le stock de suore entre les mains do la Société doit être considérable et le déficit dans la consommation moudisie est évalué 4 plus da 1 million de tonne». Les résultat» financiers de l'exerdoe en cour», qui prendra fiu au 31 Octobre, seront donc sous précédents. Le» prix moyens du sucre sur le marché d'Alexandrie étaient pour lespafns de P.T. 56 lé catitar en 1992-1903, P.T. 61 en 1903-1904 et P.T. 90 en 1904-1905, Les prix uut augmenté dans lus même» proportions pour le sucra on tablettes, cou cassé, pilé, mais un peu moins pour le granulé.

La différence des prix entre k campagne 1992 03 et celle de 1994-05 accuse nue aug mentation de près de 70%, en faveur de l'exercice actuel. De plus ta production égyp­tienne $ui était on 199203 de «6.509 sac* u dû atteindre environ TUQ.IWO sacs l'année der- mère, chiffra qui aéra nécessairement dépassé cette anute ci.
Cette augmentation considérable doproduc- tiou a penui» d'abaisser le» frai» de fabrication à un chiffre qu'on n'aurait osé espérer.

Pour l'exercice 1902 03, k Société des Sucreries et Uaffiut-rie a distribué un divi­dende de 10 % aux actionnaires; on peut donc s'attendra pour l'exercice actuel qui bénéficie d'une plus-value do 70 %, sur la vente d'une production double comme quantité, à un divi­dende beaucoup plus fort.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: MOUNTED INFANTRY SPORTS AT WADY NATROUN.

The M.L., under Major Pine-Coffin, D.S. O, old most successful sports on the 24th at the Oasis of Wady Natroun,, wbere they at present bolding their quarterly encampment. The ground was very kindly lent, and every assistant given by Mr. Bensilum, the hospitable manager of the Salt and Soda company. The ground presented at most picturesque appearance, as nearly all the Bedouins from the surroundings desert attended dressed in their beet gala costumes, and all armed with long tint-lock guns, pistols, etc. Several of them brought their families, or which a harem .lent was erected. The ladies cooked very picturesque and seemed to thoroughly enjoy themselves. Quito a novel sight was afforded by the monks from the neighboring Coptic monasteries, who turned up in great force. Their sombre costume and black turbans aflorded a striking contrast to the other spectators. The tug of war between the three Motions -raw one of the most popular items. The final pull between the Brigade Motion and the 2nd Royal Berks was a magnificent one, and lasted about 12 minutes, resulting in a win tor the Berks. "The 'picketing out race" was won 'easily by the luniakiiling Fusilier section, who completed their task in the short time of 12 minutes. The last race on the program was a "bun and treacle race," which seemed far more pleasant to watch than to take part in. The prizes were distributed at the end of the sports by Mins Dolly Pine-Coffin. Amongst those present we noticed Major Pine-Coffin, D.S.O., Mrs. Pine-Coffin and Master Miss Pine-Coffin, Mrs. Lewellin, Capt. Nuuu, D.S.0., Ghumous Sarabamon, Bishop of Khartoum, Capt, R.C Wilson, Amba Joabbis, Archbishop of GcJdgam, Lieut. Uruabie, Mabrook Zamuut, Jmdeh of Gawabees tribe, Lieuu Hump, higuor Botany and Mias Barany, humous ibiuiuui, bishop of Din Sorriau, Lieut. Lloyd, Miss Rose, Ghumous Maximus, bishop ol Abiuuwkir,'Mr. Beuailum, Ghumous Ayoub, Bishop of Din Amhabtahome, Ghumous MichieJ, Bishop of Din Baramous. At the end of the sports the Coptic Bishop of Khartoum mode a speech in classical Arabic, a translation of which is given below, A suitable reply was made by Msj. Fine-Coffin. The follow iug is a lint of the events and result:
Picketing out race (16 men and 1 Sargt.) —1st, luniakiiling Fusiliers 2nd, 2nd Royal Berks.

3.—Walking Match (150 yds).—lsr, Pta Ewart; 2nd, Pta. Anderson; 3rd, Pta Raymond:3rd Pta. Garrett. 4.—3 legged Race.—lst, Pta Ewart McCreanor ; 2nd, Ptos. Allan and McShaae j 3rd, Ftes, Gallagher and Percy. ' 5.—Native Girls' Race (carrying buckets of water on head).—1st, Sarifa Said •, 2nd, Mabrook Abdalla. Б..Tug of war (Saises v. Wadi Natroons). —1st, Wadi Natroons. 7.—Bedouins' Race (350 yds.).—1st, Ibrahim Fadalla; 2nd, Mahomed Denrish; 3rd, Abdulla Mahomed. g.—Tug of war (Final). — 2nd Royal Berks. 9—Donkey Race (Sergeants)-—1st, Sgt. Chambers; 2nd, Sgt. Noble. 10 —Officers Donkey Race—1st, Maj. Pine Coffin ; 2nd, Lt- Crosbie ; 3rd,Copt.Wilson. 11.— Bun and Treacle Race, — 1st, Azac Farak; 2nd, Mabrook. 'The following is a translation of the Bishop of Khartoum's speech: Ladies and Gentlemen,—We are very pleased on this great day to have amongst us the commandant of the British troops, and from the bottom of our hearts we wish him welcome. His presence lighted the Wadi, and aaa the inhabitants of the place as well as the priests bf the monasteries are much plesed with his visit. Before the arrival of the commandant and the troops the sun had disappeared here and now ho appears again. All the people hare and the manager of the Wady estate am very much honored by his visit to us end I cannot find any words to express the contentment of the priests on the occasion. We are praying God to protect H.M. Edward VII, King of England, H.H. Abbas II, our Khedive, our H. the Patriarch and his colleague, Father Samerion. It is by the request of all the people of the Wady Natroum that I pronounce these few words, which I am happy to say come from the bottom of my heart. I wish yon all, ladies and gentlemen, prosperity and long life. FOOTBALL. McKEBVOR SHIELD. The above teams met on the 23rd inst. at Abbearich to decide who should hold the above trophy, kindly presented by the Hon. Mr. McKeevor. Loth teams received a great ovation on entering the arena. At the appointed rime (or starting the referee, Mr. R McAllister, D.C.M., lined his men out in the following order: F. Company 1st, goal, Fortin; backs, Peggs and Page: half-backs,Calvin, Collion: , and Edwards; forwards, Smyth, Harbinson, Duffy, Galbraith, and Linton. P. Company 2nd, goal, McCallion; backs, Cohee and Reilley ; half-back, Elliot, Templeton, and McTeague; forwards, Reford, Magee, Mullan, Paton, and Judson Captain Magee guested correctly the spin of the coin and decided to defend the roadside goal. About 800 would be pretest when Smyth started the ball scrolling. Edward the first to get away and sent well into goal, but McCallion saved well. On the kick-off Mullan got away and passing out to his right Refold got possession and sent in a grasshopper to Parris, who in saving conceded a corner. This was well taken by Buford, and Magee getting the leather at his toe had no difficulty in scoring first blood for the seconds, the custodian not having an earthly chance to save. On, resuming Harbinson got on a good run and passing out to Smyth, who was given offside, this relieved matters for a while The second pressed for a while and Reford from a nice centre by Magee made the seconds 2 to nil amidst deafening cheers. Shortly after this Judaea had a good chance to score, but his shot went on the wrong side. The excitement was now intense as Paton, with a beauty, recorded the third goal. Collins, Smyth, and Harbinson now turned the tide by making tracks for McCallion, but the latter, along with Cohee and Reilley, was all O. K. The right wing of the seconds was now doing some grand work and gave Partis plenty to do, the latter being ably supported by Peggs and Page. Shortly after halftime was announced, the following being the score:— F Company. 2nd …………3 Goals F Company 1st... ... ..........Nil Alter the usual refreshments both teams entered the arena once more, The first thing noticeable was a good run by Beford, who after dodging a couple of opponents sent well in to Partis, who saved finely. Play was now carried towards midfield, but Smyth could not get away and Templeton got away on his own and shot strongly into goal, Partis felling in the attempt to save. Everything now rated in favor of the seconds, who added a filth goal per Mulian. There was only one team in the game so for as one can readily guess. The first eleven now woke up, but Smyth, when in a good position to score, was given offside. This, however, did not keep them away, and McCallion got plenty to do, which he did in a masterly fashion. However, he had to bow down to Peggs, who scored the first goal for the first eleven amidst cheers. This helped to pat the seconds on their mettle and Beford grazed the crossbar. Shortly after the crossbar fell from a great shot from Paton. Darkness was now setting in. Still the spectators urged their favorites to go in and win; Fall rime was now approaching, as Page handled the ball The free, however, proved unproductive, Duffy clearing. The referee was very strict in his decisions. Mullan, Magee and Reford were now combining well and Page could not master the right wing, who wore a terror to the defense. Play was in midfield when the whistle sounded full time. The fioal score was: F Company 2nd R. L... ... ... 5 Goals F, Company 1stR.L,,. ... ... 1 Goal Mr.P.McAlliater refereed to the satisfaction of all concerned.

div.head: GROSS CRUELTY TO BIRDS.
div.p: To toe Editor the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—I wish to bring before the notice of your readers a moot distressing case witnessed by a party of four from this house on Sunday, the 26th inst, when returning from the Barrage on No. 1 of the Tramways Co.'s. Steamboats. A native had caught about 40 young sparrows and tied them by the legs to a piece of string about 2 feet long- To get the birds within this limit they were packed all-round the string, only the heads arid breasts appearing, thus looking like a solid column of quivering life. The string was tied so tightly that in some cases the birds in struggling had severed their legs, others, more timid, had died. Over this mass of life and death a crowd was gloating and bargaining for the birds, themselves should one be too weak to move, it was thrown out to drown. We obtained the lot, and liberated them. About two-thirds reached the banks, some minus a leg, and the rest had either died, or were too weak to sustain their flight and fell into the water. Should such a thing be tolerated 1 We are, I think, getting beyond the barbaric age, and I, for my part, will do my best to prevent a recurrence of such a ghastly sight, if it wore only for the mute appeal of the birds themselves, and not considering the "ascendancy" of man, which is only too obvious in this case. I do not know whether a law exists relating to this, as If 1 had been acquainted with it, the offenders would have been treated differently. — 1 am, eta Leonard H, Dolman. Maison Spiro, Sharia Knar-el-Nil, March 27.

div.head: "A QUEER GRAMMAR."
div.p: To the Editor or the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir,—If "Grammarian" had written a polite letter in reply to my review of Dirr's Colloquial Arabic Grammar I would take the trouble to prove to him that I was right in every instance, but filling his letter with abuses and sneers as he has done, I have no alternative but to lay it down with & smile upon my lips. I may, however, inform him that he is wrong also in supposing that I am foreign to the Arabic: tongue.—yours very truly,The Whites of tub Review, Alexandria, March 27.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
